top_comment.text:
What a great video of how to truly overcome poverty, this guy made a bad 
choice but is now making good choices. He was given a second chance and is 
not asking for a handout only needed a bit of help. He is the example we 
should all follow. ﻿
top_comment.author: Brett Koger

comments.text:
+dan hayes I did not miss the point, I only emphasized one point. Yes there 
was a great act of kindness, which is an example we should all follow as 
well. What my point is, this homeless man made an effort to better himself, 
he worked hard to make it. I don't consider what this man got, laptop, 
books, and training, handouts. To him they are the tools to change his 
situation. Plus, he didn't go "asking" for it, it was given to him. Which 
is different. Also, it isn't so much the homeless that are asking for 
handouts, otherwise they probably wouldn't be homeless. 

You are correct, Patrick's humanity is also an example we should all 
follow. If everyone would follow the example of both the men and the woman 
from Google the world would be a better place.

Thanks for pointing out the part that I did not focus on.
comments.author: Brett Koger

comments.text:
It's really sad that you missed the point of the video. It's not entirely 
about how to overcome poverty; it's about how an act of kindness and 
goodwill payed off, as well as being good to your fellow man. The homeless 
guy is a person and Patrick treated him as a person who needed help. If 
anything HE is the example to follow. Look how the woman from google 
followed his example and gave the homeless man her laptop. Patrick's 
humanity spread. Try to learn from his example and not be so quick to judge 
people who might be "asking for a handout". That image of homeless people 
is starting to get tired!
comments.author: dan hayes

top_comment.text:
I honestly don't understand the level of cynicism Patrick got when he first 
announced he was going to give a laptop to a homeless man.  I mean, it's 
his money and laptop.  He can do with it whatever he wants.  Anybody know 
why those people responded the way they did?  ﻿
top_comment.author: StreetRat

comments.text:
Because he didn't just do it privately, Patrick drew a lot of public 
interest by writing about the story.  People are naturally skeptical. 
 Think of it this way: "For every action there's an equal and opposite 
reaction".  And also: "First they ignore you, then they laugh at you, then 
they fight you, then you win."  Unfortunately, this is human nature.

comments.text:
I guess you can't read English.  Nowhere did I belittle programming, but I 
did say that this homeless guy was never going to have even a childlike 
ability with programming.  Also, if you learned to tag people when you 
reply, maybe I would have had a chance to read your comment when it 
happened instead of having to reply six months later.  Either way, an error 
is still an error, and it is never a waste of time to point out other's 
flawed English.
comments.author: Kyle Schlapkohl

comments.text:
+Kyle Schlapkohl okay. let's revive a post from six months ago then. I 
pointed out, as others did, that there are actual arrogant gestures to 
consider on the internet and your response is to tag me with a bunch of 
people for grammatical errors? This is petty and a waste of your time. 

I disagreed with you calling Patrick arrogant for teaching a REAL skill 
which reflects where the US industry is going. Maybe you can explain why 
you disagree rather than playing Microsoft Word's spell check, going into 
semantics about what real skills are, belittling programming and 
programmers, and boasting about how famous you are. 

and fyi-the industrial revolution is over -"hard" life skills (I think you 
mean manual labor) don't guarantee you a job--not anymore.
comments.author: Chantal Eyong

comments.text: k?
comments.author: RADRyan5Ds

comments.text:
+Hasit Mistry +Vertoxis HammerSnatch +chris neto +RADRyan5Ds +Nathanael 
Coyne +Chantal Eyong +HariVIyer +42 Belvedere +WJR339007 +James Gruta +
pinkee12491 +BoW HitUrGSpot +Ritesh Tripathy +OstropoloS +Neena Daniw de 
Leon +CallOfDutyProject1 To all the people whose name I've listed here, you 
made an error in your grammar or spelling...if you were one of the lucky 
ones who also called me a fool, please go to a dictionary and look up the 
term.  Before you comment, learn how to make use of the English language.  

To everybody else...I misspoke in my previous post.  I was not suggesting 
that programming isn't a life skill, but that programming isn't a life 
skill he can master, or even acquire to a degree that is acceptable by 
normal standards.  In this day and age, children can program apps that are 
worth millions of dollars to tech companies, the fact that he can barely 
code an app for a smart phone shows that he lacks any true talent and 
wouldn't even be noticed if not for the novelty of a homeless guy knowing a 
bit of code.  The reason I suggest that he should pick up a hard life skill 
is because while he's simply a novelty at programming, he might be able to 
break his back as a construction worker or other labor-intensive job for 
years to come and earn the American dream.  It's incredibly doubtful that 
he'll ever be able to earn any money from coding, since there's a surplus 
of talent in the market now, once the novelty wears off he's going to find 
his skills not only outdated, but primitive in comparison to today's 
current engineers.  

While I can understand defending your craft, you people definitely fit the 
stereotype of the angry, virginal computer nerds I've heard so much about 
in the US.  It's amazing how many of your commented on a single post, 
albeit poorly worded, of mine.  Sad really...

+AG Entertainment Your comment was so stupid I felt the need to reply 
specifically to you.  To answer your question, the reason I don't do 
construction is because I have mastered my talents to such a degree that I 
earn money and public recognition from them.  I don't do something as a 
novelty that will never be up to par.  To highlight my point, my name has 
been in the #1 selling record in the US...what have you done with your 
life?  Even if, by some miracle you've had kids, in 1000 lifetimes they'd 
never equal, or be remembered half-as-well as, what I've done in a half a 
life.
comments.author: Kyle Schlapkohl

top_comment.text:
Inspiring and very decent, but if he wants to help the "unjustly homeless" 
I'd sure like to know how he defines the "justly homeless".﻿
top_comment.author: Anne-Elizabeth Hawley

comments.text: That's why he gave him the choice for a hundred dollars or a handy skill
comments.author: Gregory Kanniard

comments.text:
Believe it or not some of the homeless in my neck of the wood choose to be 
homeless. At least that's what they say. I talked to one and he spoke about 
it as if it were a lifestyle. He also rejected my diet coke because of the 
"Aspartame" which I found highly amusing.
comments.author: lacountess

comments.text:
+Your Best Friend 99.999%? That's a bit high. I don't know about the 
homeless people around you but living in SF, a lot of the homeless people 
here are addicts. Plain and simple. Not all of them obviously. but a good 
amount are. You can tell by their jitters, lack of teeth, and other side 
effects. Others have mental issues and others are just down and out. To say 
99% is pretty ridiculous. 99% of homeless in Patrick's case.
comments.author: Edward Kwong

comments.text: +Your Best Friend So child molesters are unjustly homeless
comments.author: Scalticus :0

comments.text:
There doesn't have to be a justly homeless for someone to be unjustly 
homeless.  99.999% of homeless people are unjustly homeless, there are 
probably a few people i.e. gang bangers etc, that probably don't deserve a 
whole lot, but then again even they didn't grow up with any real 
opportunities.
comments.author: Your Best Friend
